'''McFly''' are an English [[pop music|pop]] band<ref>{{cite web|url =https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/entertainment/music/news/mcfly-re-records-number-one-song-in-aid-of-nhs-39135604.html |title=McFly re-records number one song in aid of NHS |work=Belfast Telegraph}}</ref> formed in London in 2003. The band took their name from the ''[[Back to the Future (franchise)|Back to the Future]]'' character [[Marty McFly]]. The band consists of [[Tom Fletcher]] (lead vocals, guitar, and piano), [[Danny Jones]] (lead vocals, harmonica, and guitar), [[Dougie Poynter]] (bass guitar, vocals) and [[Harry Judd]] (drums). They were signed to [[Island Records]] from their 2004 launch until December 2007, before creating their own label, [[Super Records]].<ref name="SuperRecords">{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/showbiz/3am/2008/05/17/we-re-gonna-mcfly-solo-lads-tell-record-label-89520-20420212/ |title=We're gonna McFly solo lads tell record label Tag |work=Daily Mirror |access-date=18 May 2008 |date=17 May 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706185806/http://www.mirror.co.uk/showbiz/3am/2008/05/17/we-re-gonna-mcfly-solo-lads-tell-record-label-89520-20420212/ |archive-date=6 July 2008 }}</ref>

McFly rose to fame after fellow band [[Busted (band)|Busted]], with whom they later formed McBusted, helped launch them by inviting them to tour in 2004. In 2005, they won the [[Brit Award]] for Best British Pop Act.<ref>[http://www.brits.co.uk/artist/mcfly "McFly BRITs Profile"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526035101/http://www.brits.co.uk/artist/mcfly |date=26 May 2013 }}. Brits.co.uk. Retrieved 21 November 2012</ref> McFly's debut album ''[[Room on the 3rd Floor]]'' debuted at number 1 in the [[UK Album Chart]] and is certified as [[British Phonographic Industry|double platinum]];<ref name="BPI-RTTF">{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumright.asp?rq=search_plat&r_id=31989 |title=BPI Certification for Room on the Third Floor |access-date=23 November 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071018091349/http://bpi.co.uk/platinum/platinumright.asp?rq=search_plat&r_id=31989 |archive-date=18 October 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> this led to them becoming known as the youngest band ever to have an album debut at number one—a title taken from [[the Beatles]].<ref name="ilike">{{cite web|url=http://www.ilikemusic.com/pop/McFly_The_Heart_Never_Lies_Greatest_Hits-4181/2 |title=McFly – The Heart Never Lies single / Greatest Hits Album |access-date=23 November 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223070122/http://www.ilikemusic.com/pop/McFly_The_Heart_Never_Lies_Greatest_Hits-4181/2 |archive-date=23 December 2007 }}</ref> A month after the album was released, the band had their first UK headlining tour.<ref name="RTTF Tour">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=411 |title=Only a few tickets left for McFly tour! |work=McFly Official |date=25 August 2004 |access-date=23 November 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709061729/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=411 |archive-date=9 July 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref>

The band's second album, ''[[Wonderland (McFly album)|Wonderland]]'', which was released in 2005, also charted at number 1 in the UK<ref name="T40-Wonderland">{{cite web| url=http://acharts.us/album/16942|title=McFly Wonderland Music charts|website=αCharts|access-date=11 December 2009}}</ref> making them the youngest band to have topped the UK album charts twice.<ref>{{cite book|title=Guinness World Records 2007 "Youngest double toppers"|date=29 September 2006|publisher=Guinness World Records Limited|isbn=1-904994-11-3|page=98}}</ref> Their third album, ''[[Motion in the Ocean]]'', was released on 6 November 2006 and charted at number 6 in the UK.<ref name="Top40Albums">{{cite web|url=http://www.theofficialcharts.com/top40_albums_last.php?week=53&end=12/11/2006%20-%2018/11/2006&dare |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229050035/http://www.theofficialcharts.com/top40_albums_last.php?week=53&end=12%2F11%2F2006%20-%2018%2F11%2F2006&dare |url-status=dead |archive-date=29 December 2007 |title=The Official UK Charts Company 11/12/2006 |work=The Official Charts Company |date=11 December 2006 |access-date=24 November 2007}}</ref> McFly released their ''[[All the Greatest Hits]]'' compilation album on 5 November 2007, which charted at number 4 in the UK.<ref name=occ>{{cite web|title=McFly – Full Official Chart History|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/artist/15088/mcfly/|website=Official Charts Company|publisher=Official Charts Company|access-date=20 January 2016}}</ref> The band's fourth studio album, ''[[Radio:Active]]'', was given away for free as a supplement in the ''[[Mail on Sunday]]'' on 20 July 2008, before being released in the conventional manner (via physical release) on 2 September 2008. Fifth album ''[[Above the Noise]]'' was released in November 2010 and charted at number 20. 

In November 2013, it was announced that McFly would be joining forces with Busted to form the "supergroup" [[McBusted]]. They played a 34-date tour with both Busted and McFly songs.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/mcbusted-mcfly-busted-become-supergroup-2719950|title=McBusted: McFly and Busted become supergroup 2014 tour dates for supergroup|last=McGeorge|first=Alistair|date=11 November 2013|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|access-date=19 February 2014}}</ref> The only member of the original groups not to participate in the new lineup was former Busted singer [[Charlie Simpson]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/mcbusted-boybands-mcfly-and-busted-to-form-supergroup-8933220.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220512/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/news/mcbusted-boybands-mcfly-and-busted-to-form-supergroup-8933220.html |archive-date=12 May 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=Boybands McFly and Busted to form supergroup for UK tour|last=Denham|first=Jess|work=[[The Independent]]|date=11 November 2013|access-date=15 November 2013}}</ref> After Simpson's return to Busted in November 2015, McFly made a return and sold out their Anthology Tour in September 2016. After that, the band took an indefinite hiatus, with their Twitter account confirming that the boys were focusing on solo projects in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=McFly Twitter Statement|url= https://www.twitter.com/mcflymusic/status/973948396938645504|website=Twitter|access-date=15 March 2018|date=14 March 2018}}</ref> In January 2019, Poynter confirmed via a podcast that the band would be reforming that year with a new album and tour.<ref name="reunion">{{cite web|title=McFly announce reunion plans — including their first album in 9 years|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/a25752061/mcfly-reunion-plans-new-album/|website=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=5 January 2019|date=5 January 2019}}</ref> In September the band announced a new album of previously unreleased material and a concert at [[the O2 Arena]] in November 2019,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-49647089|title='McFly is forever': The boyband is back|date=10 September 2019|via=www.bbc.com}}</ref> followed by a 2020 come-back arena tour, this would however be delayed to 2021 due to the COVID-19 pandemic. Their sixth album, ''[[Young Dumb Thrills]]'', was released in 2020.<ref name="list.co.uk">{{Cite web|url=https://www.list.co.uk/article/111566-mcfly-confirm-2020-uk-tour-dates-find-out-how-to-get-tickets/|title=McFly confirm 2020 UK tour dates, find out how to get tickets|date=17 September 2019|website=The List}}</ref>

According to the [[British Phonographic Industry]] (BPI), McFly has been certified for 2 million albums and 2.2 million singles in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/certified-awards.aspx |title=Certified Awards |publisher=Bpi.co.uk |access-date=4 March 2019}}</ref> and more than 10 million records worldwide. As of 2016, McFly have had 18 consecutive UK top 20 singles, seven of which reached number one in the [[UK Singles Chart]] and fifteen of which were consecutive top ten singles.

==History==
===2002–2004: Formation and ''Room on the 3rd Floor''===
In 2001, [[Tom Fletcher]] auditioned for [[Busted (band)|Busted]],<ref name="beatsbar">{{cite web|url=http://www.thebeatsbar.co.uk/ccinterviews/mcfly.html |title=McFly Interview by CMU's Chris Cooke |date=December 2005 |access-date=23 November 2007 |work=CMU Beats Bar |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071217185503/http://www.thebeatsbar.co.uk/ccinterviews/mcfly.html |archive-date=17 December 2007 }}</ref> but lost out on the place to [[Charlie Simpson]]. Fletcher was originally accepted as part of Busted's line-up, but [[Island Records]] went on to reassess the situation and eventually decided to have the band as a three-piece rather than a four-piece. Though the record label decided against offering Fletcher a place in Busted, they were intrigued by his songwriting talents and later offered him a place on Busted's songwriting 'team', alongside band member (and already accomplished songwriter) [[James Bourne]], whom Fletcher credits with helping him to compose melodies.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Warner|first=Sam|date=18 November 2013|title=10 Things About... McBusted|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/showbiz/10-things-about/a531065/10-things-about-mcbusted/|access-date=9 August 2020|website=Digital Spy|language=en-GB}}</ref>

While writing Busted's second album, ''[[A Present for Everyone]]'', Fletcher was asked by the record label if he was available to film auditions for a new band, [[V (band)|V]]. It was at this time that Jones and Fletcher met for the first time; [[Danny Jones]] went to the audition mistaking the band to be an instrumental band rather than the conventional, all-singing, all-dancing boyband, for which they were intended.<ref name="Guardian04">{{cite news|url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/fridayreview/story/0,,1266615,00.html|title=Mad about the boys|author=Alexis Petridis|access-date=23 November 2007|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London}}</ref> Fletcher was impressed with Jones' unique style and so approached and invited him to write with himself and Bourne. When writing projects for Busted had come to an end, the two began collaborating for their own (yet unnamed) band and, eventually, moved into the [[InterContinental|InterContinental Hotel]] in London for two months, (while still receiving help from Bourne)<ref name="RTTFofic">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=310 |title=Debut McFly album track by track |access-date=23 November 2007 |work=McFly Official |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051039/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=310 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> to concentrate on writing together. Bassist [[Dougie Poynter]] and drummer [[Harry Judd]] were subsequently recruited via a classified advertisement in the ''[[NME]]'' magazine.<ref name="beatsbar"/> The pair, both Essex lads, coincidentally turned up at the same audition and got to talking over their shared appreciation of the band [[The Starting Line]], after Poynter noticed their name and logo was printed on Judd's T-shirt.

McFly's early sound was surf/pop rock. Their debut single, "[[5 Colours in Her Hair]]", released 29 March 2004, entered the [[UK Singles Chart]] at number 1 in April 2004 and stayed there the following week.<ref name="T40-5C">{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/song/1509|title=McFly 5 Colours in Her Hair Music charts|website=αCharts|access-date=11 December 2008}}</ref> In July 2004 their second single, "[[Obviously (song)|Obviously]]", also topped the charts.<ref name="T40-O">{{cite web|url=http://acharts.us/song/1617|title=McFly Obviously Music charts|website=αCharts|access-date=11 December 2007}}</ref> This was followed by the album ''[[Room on the 3rd Floor]]'' debuting at number 1 in the [[UK Albums Chart]].<ref name="Guardian04"/> It would go on to be certified [[Music recording sales certification|double platinum]] by the [[British Phonographic Industry]].<ref name="BPI-RTTF"/> The album broke records, as McFly earned an award from [[Guinness World Records]] for being the youngest band to have a debut album enter the charts in the top position, a distinction previously held by [[The Beatles]].<ref name="ilike"/> The idea for the album name came from where Jones and Fletcher wrote most of the songs for the album: room 363 in the InterContinental Hotel in London.<ref name="RTTFofic"/> The third single, "[[That Girl (McFly song)|That Girl]]", was released on 6 September 2004, placing at number 3.<ref name=occ/> The fourth single, [[Room on the 3rd Floor (song)|Room on the 3rd Floor]], the album's title track, was released on 15 November 2004 and reached number 5.<ref name="RTTFS5">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=542 |title=No.5 – Thanks |work=McFly Official |date=21 December 2004 |access-date=23 November 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051059/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=542 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> McFly supported Busted on their nationwide arena tour<ref name="Guardian04"/> along with V in February 2004 and then had their first headlining tour in September 2004.<ref name="RTTF Tour"/>

===2004–2007: ''Wonderland'' and ''Motion in the Ocean''===

In March 2005, McFly released a [[double A-side]] of "[[All About You/You've Got a Friend]]" from their second album, ''[[Wonderland (McFly album)|Wonderland]]'', which featured a 60-piece orchestra. The single reached number 1 for a week on 13 March 2005, with all profits donated to [[Comic Relief]].<ref name=occ/><ref name="CBBCAfrica">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/cbbcnews/hi/newsid_4310000/newsid_4315100/4315193.stm|title=McFly in Africa for Comic Relief|work=[[CBBC (TV channel)|CBBC]] [[Newsround]]|access-date=23 November 2007|date=3 March 2005}}</ref> The video for "You've Got a Friend" was shot in Uganda, Africa, which McFly visited for to raise awareness for the cause.<ref name="AAY/YGF">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=586|title='All About You' double A side with 'You've Got A Friend'|work=McFly Official|access-date=23 November 2007|date=7 February 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051104/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=586 <!-- Bot retrieved archive -->|archive-date=24 December 2007}}</ref><ref name="YGAFclip">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=609 |title=You've Got a Friend video clip |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=11 February 2005 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051109/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=609 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Several months later, on 2 July, McFly co-headlined [[Live 8 concert, Chiba|Live 8 Japan]], with [[Björk]] and [[Good Charlotte]] and also took part in the [[Live 8 concert, London|London concert]] at [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]]. The second single from ''Wonderland'', "[[I'll Be OK]]", was released in the UK on 15 August 2005 and scored them their fourth UK number 1.<ref name="occ" /> The album itself was released on 29 August 2005 entering at number 1.<ref name="occ"/> The third single from ''Wonderland'', "[[I Wanna Hold You]]", was released on 17 October 2005 with an unknown song Easy Way Out on the single and it gave them their 6th top 3 single.<ref name=occ/> Their fourth and final single, "[[Ultraviolet/The Ballad of Paul K]]" from ''Wonderland'' was released on 12 December 2005 and reached number 9.<ref name=occ/> McFly headlined their Wonderland Arena Tour, which started on 15 September 2005, supported by [[Tyler James (English musician)|Tyler James]] and Famous Last Words. A DVD of the tour, recorded live at the [[Manchester Evening News Arena|MEN Arena]] in Manchester, was released on 28 November.<ref name="dvd05">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=938 |title=The Wonderland Tour 2005 Out now! |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=30 November 2005 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051134/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=938 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The band also played at the 2005 [[Royal Variety Performance]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/wales/4454382.stm|title=Comic asks if Queen is 'bovvered'|access-date=23 November 2007|work=[[BBC News]]|date=22 November 2005}}</ref> [[Nemesis (roller coaster)|Nemesis]], an inverted roller coaster at the [[Alton Towers]] theme park was renamed Wonderland for a month in 2005 to celebrate the album's release. The band were filmed riding Nemesis with competition winners by music show [[CD:UK]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=826 |title=Wonderland is No.1! |access-date=9 March 2009 |work=McFly Official |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060727105916/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=826 |archive-date=27 July 2006 }}</ref>

In 2006, McFly turned their attentions to the United States, appearing in the [[Lindsay Lohan]] movie ''[[Just My Luck (2006 film)|Just My Luck]]'',<ref name="JMLIMDB">{{cite web| url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0397078/|title=Just My Luck (2006)|work=[[IMDb]]|access-date=23 November 2007}}</ref> released on 12 May, three days after the soundtrack of the movie, which comprised McFly songs taken from both ''Room on the 3rd Floor'' and ''Wonderland'',<ref name="JMLBBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/4879210.stm|title=American stardom awaits for McFly|work=BBC News|author=Peter Bowles|access-date=23 November 2007}}</ref> as well as a new version of "Five Colours in Her Hair". The band played several gigs in Los Angeles and New York,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1076 |title=Back from the States |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=20 April 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070610050659/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1076 |archive-date=10 June 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> as well as attending the American premiere of ''Just My Luck'' in [[Hollywood, Los Angeles|Hollywood]].<ref name="JMLBBC"/>

[[File:McFly gig Nottingham 2006 MMB 02c.jpg|thumb|[[Tom Fletcher]] of McFly performs onstage at Nottingham Arena during McFly's ''Motion in the Ocean'' Tour in 2006.]]

McFly's first single of 2006 was "[[Please, Please]]", released in the UK as a double A-side with a cover of the [[Queen (band)|Queen]] hit "[[Don't Stop Me Now]]" on 17 July as the official song for [[Sport Relief|Sport Relief 2006]].<ref name="SR06">{{cite web|url=http://www2.sportrelief.com/about/gallery |title=Gallery of Highlights (2006) |work=[[Sport Relief]] |access-date=23 November 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071102195752/http://www2.sportrelief.com/about/gallery/ |archive-date=2 November 2007}} Picture 14 of 19.</ref><ref name="SR06a">{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1133 |title=Lets Make McFly the UK's official number 1 this Sunday 23rd July!! |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=21 July 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224050930/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1133 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> It reached number 1 in the UK charts on 23 July, making it the band's fifth number 1 single of their career. On 14 September 2006, it was confirmed via an email newsletter from McFly's official website that the third album would be called ''[[Motion in the Ocean]]''.<ref>{{cite mailing list|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com | title=New Artwork Revealed!|mailing-list=McFlyOfficial.com Email Newsletter|date=14 September 2007| access-date =27 November 2007}} {{full citation needed|date=October 2021}}</ref> The album was released on 6 November 2006 and reached number 6.<ref name="Top40Albums" /> The second release from the album, "[[Star Girl (song)|Star Girl]]" was released on 23 October 2006, to promote the album.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1166 |title=Premiere of New McFly single Star Girl |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=19 September 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070624133316/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1166 |archive-date=24 June 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> "Star Girl" reached number 1 in its first week.<ref name=occ/> The third release from the album, "[[Sorry's Not Good Enough/Friday Night]]", was released on 18 December 2006, and reached number 3 in the UK singles charts. "Friday Night" is featured in the movie ''[[Night at the Museum]]'', which was released on 22 December 2006, in Canada and the US and 26 December 2006, in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1249 |title=New McFly double A single: Dec 18th |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=12 December 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630163132/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1249 |archive-date=30 June 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Their next single, "[[Baby's Coming Back/Transylvania]]", was released on 7 May 2007, becoming the band's seventh number 1.<ref name=occ/> The original single release date was due to be 26 February,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1277 |title=Transylvania: Mcfly's new single Feb 26th |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=29 January 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223093100/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1277 |archive-date=23 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> but the band took up the offer to return at that time to the town of Kamwokya in Uganda, which they previously visited for [[Comic Relief]] in 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1280 |title=McFly spread the Comic Relief news |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=29 January 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051010/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1280 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> Until 1 January 2016,"Baby's Coming Back/Transylvania" held the record for the biggest fall from number one for a non-limited edition single. It fell from number 1 to number 20 after a week, matching a limited edition [[Elvis Presley]] single, "One Night". This record was broken by the 2015 [[National Health Service (England)|NHS]] charity single [[A Bridge Over You]]; after becoming the [[Christmas number one]] on 25 December 2015, the single fell to Number 29 the following week.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.everyhit.co.uk/record5.html|title=Record Breakers and Trivia : Singles : Individual Hits : Number 1s|work=EveryHit|access-date=23 November 2007}}</ref>

McFly held their Motion in the Ocean tour from 17 September 2006 and were supported by [[The Click Five]] and [[Nylon (band)|Nylon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1151 |title=Click Five from America announced as Special Guests on McFly Arena Tour |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=3 August 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070629220215/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1151 |archive-date=29 June 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nylon.is/|title=Under "Diary": "Getting Ready For McFly" (13th September 2006) to "Our Last Gig With McFly" (13th October 2006)|work=Nylon|access-date=27 November 2007|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090417021514/http://www.nylon.is/|archive-date=17 April 2009}}</ref> They also held their McFly Up Close and Personal tour, supported by [[Lil' Chris]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lilchris.co.uk/news/page1/mcfly_tour_slot_confirmed|title=McFly tour slot confirmed|work=Lilchris.co.uk|access-date=23 November 2007|date=8 February 2007|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080222000750/http://www.lilchris.co.uk/news/page1/mcfly_tour_slot_confirmed|archive-date=22 February 2008}}</ref> which started on 20 March 2007, and consisted of performing in twenty four locations not covered by their arena tours over thirty four dates.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1261 |title=Up Close And Personal Tour 2007: SOLD OUT |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=18 December 2006 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630163426/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1261 |archive-date=30 June 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref>
''Motion in the Ocean'' was re-released as a double disc edition with "Baby's Coming Back" and DVD from the Wembley show on 14 May 2007 and reached number 14.<ref name=occ/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1289 |title=Special tour edition 'Motion in the Ocean' |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=21 August 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051015/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1289 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref>

===2007–2009: ''All the Greatest Hits'', touring and ''Radio:Active''===
McFly's ''[[All the Greatest Hits]]'' compilation album was released on 5 November 2007 and reached number 4 in the charts.<ref name="occ"/> The first single from the album, [[The Heart Never Lies]], which reached number 3 in the UK singles chart,<ref name=occ/> was premiered at the [[V Festival]] in August.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1314 |title=Watch McFly rock the Virgin Tent at V! |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=24 August 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071224051021/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1314 |archive-date=24 December 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> The album also featured two new songs alongside "The Heart Never Lies", "The Way You Make Me Feel" and "Don't Wake Me Up". The band went on a 26-date Greatest Hits tour for a month, starting near the end of November 2007<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1310 |title=22 Greatest Hits Tour Dates now on sale (four others sold out) |work=McFly Official |access-date=23 November 2007 |date=11 September 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026132757/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1310 |archive-date=26 October 2007 |url-status=dead}}</ref> supported by [[Elliot Minor]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thevoidmusic.wordpress.com/2007/11/19/interview-elliot-minor/ |title=Interview: Elliot Minor |work=The Void Music |access-date=27 November 2007 |date=19 November 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211173948/http://thevoidmusic.wordpress.com/2007/11/19/interview-elliot-minor/ |archive-date=11 December 2007 }}</ref> and [[Saving Aimee]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.stalbansobserver.co.uk/display.var.1755549.0.0.php?act=complaint&cid=708188|title=Local band supporting McFly|work=St Albans Observer|access-date=19 February 2008|date=12 October 2007}}</ref> to promote the album.

On 23 February and 1 March 2008, they performed two small gigs at the Annandale Hotel in Sydney, Australia while recording ''Radio:Active''. They performed the same set list as for their Greatest Hits tour. It was here where they recorded the crowd singing "we don't care" which was later used on their single "One for the Radio".{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} A compilation album of B-Sides was also released on 3 December 2007, ''[[The Greatest Bits: B-Sides & Rarities]]'', which contains 12 B-sides of their UK singles.

On 20 May 2008, McFly confirmed that their fourth studio album would be titled ''[[Radio:Active]]'' (typeset as ''Radio:ACTIVE''). It was recorded in Australia, and given away for free as a supplement in ''[[The Mail on Sunday]]'' on 20 July 2008. It was subsequently released in stores on 22 September 2008 with four additional tracks, a DVD and a 32-page booklet. The album was announced after McFly confirmed that they had left [[Island Records]] as they were unhappy with some of the decisions that the label was making for them.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.entertainmentwise.com/news/40185/mcfly-to-quit-label-to-escape-boyband-tag|title=McFly To Quit Label To Escape Boyband Tag|work=Entertainmentwise|access-date=16 February 2008|date=26 January 2008}}</ref> Since announcing the launch of their new record label, the band have said that they "won't rule out" signing other acts, but that for the moment they're just concentrating on releasing their "own stuff".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.livingtv.co.uk/celebrity/starwords/mcfly-interview.php |title=Celebrity: McFly Interview |work=LivingTV.co.uk |access-date=7 June 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705161033/http://www.livingtv.co.uk/celebrity/starwords/mcfly-interview.php |archive-date=5 July 2008}}</ref> ''Radio:Active'' mixes their love of vintage rock with a British twist on the modern pop-rock sound.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mcfly.com/biog.aspx|title=Mcfly official website, The Band|website=Mcfly.com|access-date=29 November 2021}}</ref>[[File:FlonesHMVApollo.jpg|thumb|[[Tom Fletcher]] and [[Danny Jones]] at HMV Hammersmith Apollo, 1 May 2009.]]

The first single released from the ''Radio:Active'' album was "[[One for the Radio]]",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hereward.co.uk/article.asp?id=709276|title=McFly Confirm New Album Details Tag|work=Hereward.co.uk|access-date=20 May 2008|date=20 May 2008}}</ref> a song about as the band's "constant struggle for critical acceptance".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/entertainment/McFly-51803.html|title=McFly's super release|work=Female First|access-date=27 May 2008|date=21 May 2008}}</ref> The single was premiered on [[BBC Radio 1]]'s [[BBC Switch|Switch]] with [[Nick Grimshaw]] on 1 June 2008<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mcflyofficial.com/news/?id=1369 |title=One for the Radio |work=McFly Official |access-date=6 June 2008 |date=2 June 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080605000736/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/?id=1369 |archive-date=5 June 2008 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and was released on 14 July 2008.<ref name=MySpaceNews>{{cite web|url=http://collect.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=bandprofile.listAllShows&friendid=28129529&n=McFLY |title=Official MySpace – Calendar |access-date=27 June 2008 |work=myspace.com |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080602125404/http://collect.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=bandprofile.listAllShows&friendid=28129529&n=McFLY |archive-date=2 June 2008}}</ref> As of 25 June 2008, "One for the Radio" was included in Radio 2's A list,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio1/playlist/ |title=Playlist |work=BBC Radio1 |access-date=7 July 2008 |date=25 June 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105033008/http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio1/playlist/ |archive-date=5 November 2011}}</ref> meaning that it receives primary airplay during the daytime. The single charted at number 2 in the charts. The album was recorded, and produced in Australia. McFly performed a showcase concert on 10 July 2008 at [[Shepherd's Bush Empire]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1373 |title=Only 200 tickets left for Shepherds Bush show – on sale now |work=McFly Official |access-date=7 July 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080726224941/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1373 |archive-date=26 July 2008 |url-status=dead}}</ref> and performed another concert at [[KOKO (venue)|KOKO]] on 24 July 2008 as part of the iTunes Live Festival '08.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1372 |title=Win tickets to see McFly at the iTunes Live: London Festival 08. Entry now 16yrs + |work=McFly Official |access-date=7 July 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080618031335/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1372 |archive-date=18 June 2008 |url-status=dead}}</ref> An EP of the performance, released 4 August 2008, was made available to download from the [[iTunes Store]]. The second single from the album, "[[Lies (McFly song)|Lies]]" was released on 15 September 2008 and reached number 4 in the charts.

McFly embarked on their sixth arena tour in 2008, starting from 7 November 2008, attending 14 dates,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mcflyofficial.com/news/?id=1376 |title=2008 Arena Tour – on sale July 20 |work=McFly Official |access-date=7 July 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080706101700/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/?id=1376 |archive-date=6 July 2008 |url-status=dead}}</ref> supported by manufactured pop band [[Avenue (band)|Avenue]] and Indie pop rock band Reemer. They also performed four concerts in Brazil from 5 October 2008 to 11 October 2008. The third single from the album was "[[Do Ya/Stay With Me]]", released 23 November 2008. The song was released in aid of 2008's [[Children in Need]] and reached number 18 in the [[UK Singles Chart]], the lowest charting position of any of their singles to date, and their first single not to reach Top 10. In 2009 McFly decided to once again arrange a tour to situate smaller venues, this time being called ''Up Close... And This Time It's Personal'' starting on 18 April in [[Amsterdam]]. They then did 14 dates in the UK before going on to do 7 dates in South America including Brasil, Argentina and Chile. [[David Archuleta]], the ''[[American Idol]]'' runner up, supported them on their UK stint.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1426 |title=McFly – The Official Website |publisher=Mcflyofficial.com |access-date=16 December 2012 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090401145040/http://www.mcflyofficial.com/news/index.php?id=1426 |archive-date=1 April 2009 }}</ref>

McFly achieved their third number 1 album, ''Radio:Active'', with the [[Radio:Active – Live at Wembley]] Tour DVD on 17 May 2009. The ''Up Close... And This Time It's Personal'' tour ended on 9 June. Later this month Mcfly did 3 shows for the forestry commission, which are concerts that take place every year to raise awareness of the UK forests. They were supported by indie-rock band Vagabond. Also in June, McFly made a surprise appearance at the [[Jonas Brothers]]' show at [[Wembley Stadium]] on 15 June, joining them on stage to sing "[[Star Girl (song)|Star Girl]]".

===2010–2012: ''Above the Noise'' and ''Memory Lane: The Best of McFly''===
In Autumn 2010, McFly re-signed and partnered with their previous Label (Island Records) to create and launch an interactive website, ''Super City'', which provided fans with unprecedented access to the band. Subscribers would be able to download CDs before they were sold in stores. They would also gain access to video streams, web-chats, VIP access at gigs, and first call on tickets.<ref>McFly to Save the Music Industry? (2011). Q: The Modern guide to Music and More, 21.</ref> This website was developed in a hope to combat any leaks (piracy) and gain loyalty from their fans, as they would have access to any new materials before they could be leaked.<ref>Otter, C. (2010). 'Pioneers' Gain Website Window into Brave New World of McFly. Music Week, 6.</ref> The website had about 50,000 visitors the first day, causing the site to shut down for two weeks.<ref>Paine, A. (2010). Join the Club. Billboard – International Newsweekly of Music, Video and Home Entertainment, 17.</ref>

The first single from their fifth album, "[[Party Girl (McFly song)|Party Girl]]", was written in [[Atlanta]] with [[Dallas Austin]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a240755/mcfly-confirm-new-single-title.html|title=McFly confirm new single title|last=Love|first=Ryan|publisher=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=9 July 2010}}</ref> It premiered on 14 July on [[BBC Radio 1]] and was released on 5 September and reached number 6 in the UK charts. The "Party Girl" music video was voted number 1 by fans, in the [[4Music]] Video Honours of 2010.{{citation needed|date=December 2011}} The album, ''[[Above the Noise]]'', was released on 15 November. It debuted at number 20 in the album charts & reached number 7 in the album download charts. The second single released from the album was "[[Shine a Light (McFly song)|Shine a Light]]", a song penned with [[Taio Cruz]]. "Shine a Light" reached number 3 in the UK charts. The third single, "[[That's the Truth (McFly song)|That's the Truth]]", was released on 6 March 2011.

The band made a mini 30-minute-long movie titled ''[[Nowhere Left to Run]]'' which featured a vampire theme along with a sex scene involving Judd. The "Party Girl" video was taken from the movie. This was released on DVD on 29 November exclusively to [[HMV]] stores.

[[File:That Sunday Feeling McFly Above the Noise Tour - Forever Wear.jpg|thumb|Backstage at McFly's [[Above the Noise]] Tour]]

In August 2011, McFly announced that they would be doing a tour consisting of 26 dates around the UK in March/April 2012. On 1 November McFly teamed up with Gioia Jewellery to release their first official jewellery range designs include each member's SuperCity logo.<ref>[http://mcflyofficial.com/news/165/McFly_Official_Jewellery_available_NOW ''McFly Official Jewellery available NOW!'', McFly Official website, Undated]. Retrieved 14 December 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120111182350/http://mcflyofficial.com/news/165/McFly_Official_Jewellery_available_NOW |date=11 January 2012 }}</ref> On 4 December, Poynter won the [[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK series 11)|eleventh series]] of ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (UK TV series)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]''.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-16021195 ''McFly bassist Dougie Poynter wins I'm a Celebrity'', BBC News, 4 December 2011]. Retrieved 14 December 2011.</ref> On 17 December, Judd won the [[Strictly Come Dancing (series 9)|ninth series]] of ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]''.

On the band's latest tour, entitled ''Keep Calm and Play Louder Tour'', they showcased three brand new songs entitled "Do Whatcha", "Red" and "Touch the Rain", all of which would be on their sixth studio album.

Judd was invited to carry the [[Olympic Torch]] as part of the Olympic Torch Relay Run for the [[2012 London Olympics]]. On 4 August 2012, McFly played for a crowd of 50,000 people at an outdoor show in [[Hyde Park, London|Hyde Park]] as part of the Olympic BTLondonLive celebration.

In September 2012, McFly played four shows in America. Two at L.A.'s famed Roxy and two at New York's legendary Gramercy Theatre. All four shows sold out in less than a minute and fans lined up hours before the shows. On the American shows, they premiered another brand new song entitled "[[Love Is Easy (McFly song)|Love Is Easy]]". In 2012, it was announced an autobiography entitled ''Unsaid Things: Our Story'' would be due for release on Amazon Stores in October 2012 and to coincide with the autobiography, the band also announced that they would be releasing another Greatest Hits album. Fletcher announced on Twitter that their next single would be "Red" as it had been so well received on the tour but this was later changed to "Love Is Easy", which was released on 11 November 2012, a week before the new Greatest Hits compilation.

In September 2012, for the final Chris Moyles Show, the band put together a special video for Chris's feature McFly day, where he would normally play Star Girl every Friday (since January 2010), this latest edition was called Star Boy as a tribute, thanking Chris Moyles for playing "Star Girl" every week.

In October 2012, it was announced that they would release a greatest hits which is titled ''[[Memory Lane: The Best of McFly]]'' featuring most of the band's hits and 3 brand new songs, [[Love Is Easy (McFly song)|Love Is Easy]], "Do Whatcha" and "Cherry Cola". The album was released on 26 November 2012 and the new single "Love Is Easy" was released on 18 November 2012. It debuted at number 10, with the album following at number 21. A few weeks before "Love Is Easy" was due to go on sale, McFly announced that they would bring the release date forward a week, meaning that the new release date would be 11 November 2012. In November 2012, they also announced that they would be doing 18 tour dates in the UK between April and May 2013 in support of the album.

On 11 October 2012, McFly published their first autobiography, ''Unsaid Things: Our Story'', named after a song from their first album. The book was a tell-all story which featured exclusive information that they revealed for the first time from the band's start to their present. They shared stories about their childhoods, the band's rise to fame and even the challenges they faced along the way.

===2013–2015: Planned sixth studio album and McBusted===
McFly confirmed that they would embark an original 18-date tour (21 later) to promote their 2012 ''[[Memory Lane: The Best of McFly]]'' album which would run from April–May. They were joined for some for these dates by [[James Bourne]]. McFly went on several writing trips for the writing stage of this album and worked with [[Matt Willis]] and Bourne in writing. Titles for songs were to be "Hyperion", "Break Me", "We Were Only Kids", "Dare You To Move", "Hammer Ring", "Josephine", "[[Love Is Easy (McFly song)|Love Is Easy]]", "Do Watcha", "Cherry Cola", "Red", "[[Love Is on the Radio]]" and "Touch the Rain". "Love Is Easy" was released as a single in 2012 while "Do Watcha" and "Cherry Cola" were both featured on ''Memory Lane: The Best of McFly''. "Red" and "Touch the Rain" were both previewed during McFly's Keep Calm and Play Louder tour in 2012. "Love Is on the Radio" was previewed during McFly's 10th anniversary shows at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in 2013. "Love Is on the Radio", the first single taken from their new album, was released on 24 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pressparty.com/pg/newsdesk/HackfordJonesPR/view/91458/|title=McFly Announce new single 'Love Is on the Radio'|date=15 October 2013|publisher=Pressparty|access-date=5 August 2014}}</ref> The album was due to be released in the northern spring of 2014, but this has been put on hold. In the McBusted biography by Jennifer Parker it was hinted that the sixth album was abandoned in favour of [[McBusted (album)|the debut album of McBusted]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Parker|first1=Jennifer|title=McBusted: The Story of the World's Biggest Super Band|date=23 October 2014|publisher=Simon & Schuster UK|location=3126 of 3421|isbn=978-1-4711-4065-5|edition=Kindle}}</ref> In November 2013, the band wrote and performed the new theme tune to ''[[The Paul O'Grady Show]]''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/mcbusted-mcfly-performed-paul-ogradys-2783692|title=McBusted: McFly performed on Paul O'Grady's show as Busted watch on|author=Alistair McGeorge|work=[[Daily Mirror]]}}</ref>

[[File:McBusted performing in 2014.jpg|thumb|400px|McBusted performing in 2014]]

In late January 2013, McFly went on a writing trip with Bourne and wrote five songs. In early April, McFly uploaded a video of an acoustic live demo called 'My TVR' to their official YouTube account. The song was written with Bourne. On 19 May the band announced via their Twitter page that they would also be playing a two-date special concert at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] in celebration of their 10th anniversary as a band. Due to huge demand, two extra dates were announced. In addition, the Saturday show was streamed live from the band's website for fans who couldn't attend. During an interview with the Big Top 40 Webchat, Fletcher described the shows as his "favourite shows we've ever played".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WN3HyNhfYAU |title=McFly Big Top 40 Webchat |publisher=YouTube |access-date=5 August 2014}}</ref>{{better source needed|date=April 2020}} All four shows were held in September and featured [[McBusted]], a surprise collaboration between McFly and Busted, minus [[Charlie Simpson]]. Following the shows with Busted, the two bands announced a 30-date UK arena tour as McBusted. The McBusted Tour was the biggest tour of 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/11207666/McBusted-tour-again-It-feels-like-releasing-our-first-album.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220112/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/music-news/11207666/McBusted-tour-again-It-feels-like-releasing-our-first-album.html |archive-date=12 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=McBusted tour again: 'It feels like releasing our first album'|date=4 November 2014|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}{{cbignore}}</ref>

In 2015, they embarked on a second McBusted tour, [[McBusted's Most Excellent Adventure Tour]]. They also released a DVD following the tour.

On 21 June, a solo interview by Fletcher was published by Fabulous magazine in time for Father's Day. Fletcher stated that "McBusted was an opportunity to have fun without knowing where it would take us, but McFly is for life. McBusted has been amazing fun, but it's not where our passion is. McFly is more than a band, we live and breathe it. We want to make album number six."{{citation needed|date=April 2020}}

On a documentary with [[Fearne Cotton]], Jones confirmed that McFly have three unreleased albums.<ref>{{cite AV media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GR3_qCZpVbw|title=Fearne and McBusted Documentary Episode 1|date=21 May 2014|via=YouTube}}</ref> The band were on a hiatus but Jones hinted at a future reunion, stating "It's really nice to have a bit of breathing space after 12½ years with McFly. We've never really had this time off, so we'll give it a few months and see how we feel. When we're all refreshed, we'll go and smash an album."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tv3.ie/xpose/article/entertainment-news/191593/McFly-planning-new-album|title=McFly planning new album|work=TV3.ie – Xposé Entertainment}}</ref>

===2016: Return as McFly and The Anthology===
On 25 April 2016, the band announced that they would be going back on tour in June 2016, where they would be playing all five albums and including some original new songs for a potential new album over three dates in each of four chosen cities: Glasgow, Birmingham, Manchester and London, with the tour called "The Anthology".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/36136774/mcfly-re-form-for-anthology-tour-in-glasgow-birmingham-manchester-and-london|title=McFly re-form for Anthology tour in Glasgow, Birmingham, Manchester and London|date=26 April 2016|work=[[Newsbeat]]|publisher=[[BBC Online]]|access-date=27 April 2016}}</ref> Talking to ''1883 Magazine'', Fletcher said: "After doing two massive Arena tours with McBusted, we really wanted to do something different for this tour to herald the return of McFly. So we're playing some iconic rock venues that will allow our fans to experience the songs in a much more up close and personal environment."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.1883magazine.com/music-features/music-features/mcfly|title=mcfly - 1883 Magazine|date=26 April 2016|work=1883|access-date=27 April 2016}}</ref> They also revealed that they'll be making new music after the tour, with Judd stating, "We all agreed to go on tour first and then that will be the catalyst of what's to come." On 25 May 2016, it was announced the band would have to postpone the Anthology Tour due to Judd herniating a disc in his neck.<ref name="BBC delay">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-36382147|title=McFly postpone tour after neck injury|last=Savage|first=Mark|date=25 May 2016|publisher=[[BBC News]]|access-date=21 June 2016}}</ref> McFly eventually toured in September 2016.<ref name="BBC delay"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://supercity.mcfly.com/tour/|title=McFly|publisher=McFly.com}}</ref>

===2016–2019: Indefinite hiatus===
After the tour, the band revealed that they had scrapped two albums worth of songs recorded since ''Above the Noise''. Fletcher said: "After a certain amount of time, you feel like that was where you were at, at a moment[...] If we released stuff we recorded three years ago, we wouldn't be 100 per cent behind it any more. We still love the songs but we'd be excited about doing new things."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.list.co.uk/article/84598-mcfly-axe-two-albums/|title=McFly axe two albums|date=6 October 2016|work=[[The List (magazine)|The List]]|publisher=The List Ltd.|access-date=6 October 2016}}</ref> The following day, they announced that they would finally begin recording new material in January 2017.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/mcfly-confirm-album-six-years-8839106|title=McFly CONFIRM album six as they reveal start date for work on highly anticipated new record|last=McGeorge|first=Alastair|date=15 September 2016|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|publisher=[[Trinity Mirror]]|access-date=6 October 2016}}</ref> In December 2016, Judd revealed that the [[McBusted]]-recorded song [[McBusted (album)#Track listing|'Getting It Out']] would have appeared on the band's scrapped album. McFly's return was still in doubt, with Fletcher working on a feature-length film and regularly writing new books. Jones was said to be launching solo music and has had a new born son. In early 2018, it was announced Poynter was to go on tour with the band [[A (band)|A]]. Those tour dates are now completed and it is unknown whether Poynter will play with them again. Judd was promoting his new book 'Get Fit, Get Happy' as well as raising his new son Kit. A writing trip was last taken in January 2017 for their sixth album, otherwise no obvious progression was made towards album six.<ref>{{cite web|title=Harry Judd only skipped one song on Busted's new album|url=https://www.list.co.uk/article/87342-harry-judd-only-skipped-one-song-on-busteds-new-album/|website=The List|access-date=30 December 2016|date=22 December 2016}}</ref>

On 14 March 2018, the band confirmed via their Twitter account that they were focusing on solo projects in 2018, but looking forward to making more music in the future.<ref>{{cite web|title=McFly Twitter Statement|url= https://mobile.twitter.com/mcflymusic/status/973948396938645504|website=Twitter|access-date=15 March 2018|date=14 March 2018}}</ref> The members still supported each other on their individual projects such as Tom, Jones and Judd collaborating in March 2018.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tom Danny RAF Collab|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/Bg3uauIBF9B/ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/s/instagram/Bg3uauIBF9B |archive-date=26 December 2021 |url-access=registration|website=Instagram|access-date=29 March 2018|date=28 March 2018}}{{cbignore}}</ref> All members have stated that new music will eventually be released when the time and music is right.

Poynter started a band called Ink.<ref>{{cite web |title= ink. announcement |url= https://www.nme.com/news/music/mcfly-bassist-dougie-poynter-new-band-ink-2263373 |website=NME.com |access-date= 5 June 2018 |date= 5 June 2018}}</ref>

Judd went on tour with a production called ''Rip It Up'', a musical.<ref>{{cite web |title =Rip It Up Musical |url= https://www.ripituptheshow.com/|website= Rip It Up |access-date= 5 June 2018 |date= 5 June 2018 }}</ref>

===2019–present: ''The Lost Songs'', 2020 comeback tour and ''Young Dumb Thrills''===

On 28 December 2018, Poynter confirmed via a podcast on ''Sappenin' Podcast with Sean Smith'' that McFly would be returning from their hiatus with a new album during the year and they would also be doing a new tour during the summer.<ref name="reunion" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.msn.com/en-gb/entertainment/music/mcfly-reforming-this-year-with-new-album-planned-reveals-dougie-poynter/ar-BBROO2H?ocid=|title=McFly reforming THIS YEAR with new album planned reveals Dougie Poynter|website=www.msn.com|access-date=7 June 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite podcast |host=Sean Smith & Morgan Richards |title=Sappenin Podcast with Sean Smith |date=28 December 2018 |url=https://play.acast.com/s/sappenin/ep.5-dougiepoynter-mcfly-}}</ref>

Following this, on 9 September, the band's [[Instagram]] page posted a video of their microphone logo, accompanied by the sound of guitar feedback as the picture comes into focus.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.clashmusic.com/news/hold-up-what-are-mcfly-up-to|title=Hold Up. What Are McFly Up To?|website=Clash Magazine|language=en|access-date=9 September 2019}}</ref> This was the first post made by the page since 2017. All members of the band then proceeded to post the same thing on their personal social media profiles, announcing an ‘[[Instagram Live]]’ at 9:30am on the following day (10 September).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.twitter.com/mcflymusic/status/1171096288554868737|title=McFly|website=Twitter|access-date=9 September 2019}}</ref> The announcement involved the band's first album of new material in 9 years, ''The Lost Songs'', as well as their first ever solo show at [[the O2 Arena]] (they performed there at the 2010 [[Jingle Bell Ball]]). Following the selling-out of the O2 Show the band announced a further eleven tour dates forming an official comeback arena tour in 2020.<ref name="list.co.uk" /> However, the band rescheduled the tour three times (now called the [[Young Dumb Thrills Tour]] due to the ongoing [[COVID-19 pandemic]]; they eventually undertook the tour in September 2021.

On 2 July 2020, the band announced they had signed a new record deal with [[BMG Rights Management]] and confirmed they will be releasing their first album of new material later in the year.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-53249063|title=McFly sign first record deal for 10 years|date=2 July 2020|website=BBC News}}</ref> On 27 July 2020, the band announced their sixth studio album ''[[Young Dumb Thrills]]''. Pre-orders began 30 July 2020, with the lead single ''Happiness'' releasing on the same day.

The instant gratification single from the new album was "Growing Up" featuring [[Mark Hoppus]], released on 4 September 2020 as the second single. It failed to chart on the UK Singles Top 100 but debuted and peaked at number 80 on the Official Singles Sales Chart Top 100 on 11 September 2020.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-sales-chart/20200911/7509/|title=Official Singles Sales Chart Top 100 11 September 2020 - 17 September 2020|website=Official Charts|date=11 September 2020|access-date=6 December 2021}}</ref>

The third single was "Tonight Is The Night", released on 1 October 2020.

On 24 September 2021, they released the single "Dragonball", with lyrics making references to the [[Dragon Ball|Japanese manga/anime of the same title]]. "Dragonball" did not enter the Official UK Top 100 Chart, but debuted and peaked at number 57 on the Official Singles Sales Chart Top 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-sales-chart/20211001/7509/|title=Official Singles Sales Chart Top 100 01 October 2021 - 07 October 2021|website=Official Charts|date=1 October 2021|access-date=6 December 2021}}</ref>

On 2 December 2021, they released their cover version of "[[Walking in the Air]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Xo-9NH640iI|title=Walking in the Air|website=YouTube|date=2 December 2021|access-date=3 December 2021}}</ref> The single did not enter the Official UK Top 100 Chart, but debuted and peaked at number 25 on the Official Singles Sales Chart Top 100.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.officialcharts.com/charts/singles-downloads-chart/|title=Official Singles Downloads Chart Top 100 10 December 2021 - 16 December 2021|website=Official Charts|date=10 December 2021|access-date=10 December 2021}}</ref>

==Super Records==
[[Super Records]] Ltd. is an independent label operated and owned by McFly. Initially, McFly were signed to major record outlet [[Island Records|Universal Island Records]]. Although they have left Universal, McFly's singles are distributed by a company named "Absolute" who also distribute for acts like [[Cascada]] and [[Jay Sean]] and are part of the Universal Group.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://absolutelabelservices.com/|title=Absolute – The Label Services Business|website=absolutelabelservices.com}}</ref> Super Records was created after McFly decided to leave Island, Universal Records at the end of 2007. They returned to Island, Universal for their fifth album ''[[Above the Noise]]'' (2010).

==Influence==
{{Over-quotation|section|date=April 2020}}
McFly have been cited as having influenced a number of high-profile musicians in various different ways. [[Niall Horan]] and [[Louis Tomlinson]] of [[One Direction]], have credited McFly as the opening act of the first concert they had ever attended.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=On2yZl2iiMo|title=One Direction Talk About Their Upcoming 2013 North American Tour And First Concert Experience|website=[[YouTube]]|access-date=11 July 2014}}</ref> Speaking about meeting with the group, Jones said "it turned out that Niall and Louis were at one of our first ever shows. And they were all like, 'we copied your haircuts, and you made us want to play guitar', which is really amazing to hear. They're the biggest band in the world right now. And their favourite band was us! We influenced them. It's really strange, because you feel like a veteran!".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/whats-on/music/mcfly-play-fusion-festival-cofton-5741433|title=McFly moving on to the next chapter in their lives|access-date=12 July 2014|date=16 August 2013}}</ref> Reviews for One Direction's debut album ''[[Up All Night (One Direction album)|Up All Night]]'' had credited McFly as a notable influence,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/review/a352333/one-direction-up-all-night-album-review.html#~oJKlWfDLrkf0bO |title=One Direction: 'Up All Night' – Album review|website=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=11 July 2014|date=22 November 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailyrecord.co.uk/entertainment/music/music-news/boyband-one-direction-tell-mentor-1080349|title=Boyband One Direction tell mentor Simon Cowell: We'll take our own direction on song choice|access-date=29 July 2014|date=10 August 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://popledge.co.uk/album-review-one-direction-up-all-night-x-factor-to-superstars/ |title=ALBUM REVIEW: ONE DIRECTION 'UP ALL NIGHT' – X Factor to Superstars? |access-date=29 July 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140729162648/http://popledge.co.uk/album-review-one-direction-up-all-night-x-factor-to-superstars/ |archive-date=29 July 2014}}</ref> and Horan stated the group were very happy to have such a comparison noted.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://top40-charts.com/news.php?nid=73331|title=One Direction Reveal Their Musical Influences And Their Perfect Dates!|access-date=11 July 2014}}</ref> McFly had contributed song-writing to the first three studio albums that the group released. The group's debut featured the Fletcher-penned track ''I Want'', while the group's 2nd album ''[[Take Me Home (One Direction album)|Take Me Home]]'' featured the song ''I Would'' penned by Fletcher, Jones and Poynter. Deluxe editions of the album also featured ''Irresistible'', a track penned by all 5 members of One Direction alongside Fletcher, Jones and Poynter. This track marked the first time Jones was credited as the producer of any McFly-penned song for the group, with this trait continuing for later songs. Horan has since established a professional relationship with McFly, co-writing a number of album tracks for One Direction with Fletcher, Jones and Poynter, including the song ''Don't Forget Where You Belong'' from their 3rd album ''[[Midnight Memories]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.capitalfm.com/artists/one-direction/news/niall-horan-mcfly-2014-songs/|title=One Direction's Niall Horan Writing New Songs With McFly For Next Album |access-date=11 July 2014}}</ref> having previously credited them for teaching the group songwriting techniques.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fanpop.com/clubs/niall-horan/articles/192038/title/j-14s-phone-call-interview-with-niall-horan |title=-14's Phone Call Interview with Niall Horan |access-date=11 July 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619205032/http://www.fanpop.com/clubs/niall-horan/articles/192038/title/j-14s-phone-call-interview-with-niall-horan |archive-date=19 June 2015 }}</ref>

Horan, Fletcher, Jones and Poynter had written three songs together for the group's 4th album, due for release in late 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/NiallOfficial/status/445984259728506880|title=Niall Horan Tweet 18/03/2014|access-date=27 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/NiallOfficial/status/446083374487457792|title=Niall Horan Tweet 19/03/2014|access-date=27 July 2014}}</ref> Despite this, none of the tracks were chosen for the release, marking the first time the band were not featured on the group's songwriting credits on any studio album. However, Horan returned to work with the band for the group's 5th studio album in 2015, penning two tracks with Fletcher and Jones which were, again, not included on the album.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IVlWhJqWM5g|title=Dear Carrie: The One When I Recap|website=[[YouTube]]|access-date=25 May 2015}}</ref> On 16 June 2014, Horan told the group's audience at the [[Parken Stadium]] in Denmark that [[McBusted]] supporting the group was "something special" because "they were a lot of our favourite bands when we were growing up".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Dsq37QzcGCc|title=One Direction – Niall's talk – Copenhagen, Denmark 16.06.14|website=[[YouTube]]|access-date=11 July 2014}}</ref> One Direction have also praised McFly as role models for longevity, having stayed together as a band for over a decade. Tomlinson said "Oh, they're great role models. They've been through it, so it was really nice to have the chance to talk to them about their experiences. They've been so successful because they've managed to be themselves from the start. There aren't any egos, you know? I think that's really important in a band."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.celebuzz.com/2012-10-01/one-directions-louis-tomlinson-talks-take-me-home-liams-new-hair-cut-and-collaborating-with-psy-exclusive/|title=One Direction's Louis Tomlinson Talks 'Take Me Home,' Liam's New Hair Cut and Collaborating with Psy (EXCLUSIVE)|access-date=11 July 2014|date=October 2012}}</ref>

Also citing McFly as influences are British pop rock band [[The Vamps (British band)|The Vamps]], who supported McFly on their 2013 ''[[Memory Lane: The Best of McFly|Memory Lane tour]]''. Guitarist and vocalist [[James McVey]] stated "McFly is a band we love to be compared to over other bands, simply for the fact of their good musicianship. They write very well and they're very energetic on stage, which is something we try to replicate in our own performances."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/interviews/a518748/the-vamps-interview-we-love-mcfly-comparisons.html#~oJKEM3c32JuaYS|title=The Vamps interview: 'We love McFly comparisons'|website=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=11 July 2014|date=26 September 2013}}</ref> Drummer [[Tristan Evans]] also spoke of the band, explaining "McFly were an influence on me wanting to get into music and we feel like the next generation of their take on pop," while bassist [[Connor Ball]] continued "They're chilled-out and we hope we can have that calm attitude if we ever get that successful."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/music/news/a521970/the-vamps-want-disclosure-collaboration-it-would-be-amazing.html#~oL9wezx7MahUCU|title=The Vamps want Disclosure collaboration: "It would be amazing"|website=[[Digital Spy]]|access-date=26 July 2014|date=8 October 2013}}</ref> Frontman [[Brad Simpson (singer)|Brad Simpson]] also referred to McFly when asked about influences, stating "Their debut album was a first in all of our collections".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/new-music/10284021/The-Vamps-New-Music.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220112/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/new-music/10284021/The-Vamps-New-Music.html |archive-date=12 January 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=The Vamps – New Music|access-date=11 July 2014}}{{cbignore}}</ref> The band credited their support slot as providing an opportunity to observe the band's skills for their own development. I was a part of that era." He continued "these guys came out with instruments and they played and wrote all their own stuff and I was like, that's great – I want to do that." Band member [[Charley Bagnall]] agreed, saying, "McFly was a huge part of my life."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PrwidjkJ16E|title=Rixton On Who They Look Up To & Las Vegas Adventures|website=[[YouTube]]|access-date=19 July 2014}}</ref> Roche's mother, English singer and TV presenter [[Coleen Nolan]], said, "To me he's still that little boy I watched singing and dancing around to McFly records...I took him to their show in Manchester when he was nine or 10 and he said to me, 'Mum, one day that will be me up there.'"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/coleen-nolan-couldnt-more-proud-3915571|title=Coleen Nolan couldn't be more proud of Rixton star son – as long as he doesn't take DRUGS|work=Daily Mirror|access-date=5 October 2014|date=25 July 2014}}</ref>{{better source needed|date=April 2020}}

[[R5 (band)|R5]] has also cited McFly as an influence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://joeyvoodoo.com/2011/03/07/watch-out-here-comes-r5/|title=Watch out...here comes R5!|website=Joeyvoodoo.com|access-date=11 July 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masslive.com/television/index.ssf/2011/04/glee_riker_lynch_discusses_war.html|title='Glee': Riker Lynch talks Warblers, family band R5|website=Masslive.com|access-date=11 July 2014}}</ref> Especially in their early years the pop-rock band cited McFly as a big influence, and were a favourite of oldest band member and bassist [[Riker Lynch]], mentioning them in multiple interviews, as well as covering their songs as part of interviews as well as during sound checks and early concerts, which included covers of McFly's "That Girl" and "All About You". Plus Riker sang a cover of "Obviously" while on the Glee Live tour to which Fletcher commented, and covers of "Love is Easy", "Star Girl" and "All About You" with fans at a ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]'' event after learning of the passing of cast-mate [[Cory Monteith]].

Asked about influencing a new generation of bands, Jones stated, "There's a few bands, like the 1D boys, and they're all getting to that age where [[Busted (band)|Busted]] or McFly was the first gig they ever went to. It's really nice to see that bands are taking influence from what you do." He continued, "to actually see people in bands picking up guitars and doing their thing – any musical influence that we can give them – is amazing to see."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sugarscape.com/main-topics/music/1050820/mcbusted-talk-inspiring-bands-5sos-and-one-direction-see-people-picking-gu|title=MCBUSTED TALK INSPIRING BANDS LIKE 5SOS AND ONE DIRECTION: 'TO SEE PEOPLE PICKING UP GUITARS IS AMAZING'|website=Sugarscape.com|access-date=11 July 2014}}</ref>
